well good morning thank you very much Andrea I really appreciate and thank you

the cloud in fact innovation is good cloud is good because it helps us move off legacy
systems and our biggest risk when we look at things is indeed legacy systems now today I want to say that there have
been some substantial changes in the way the government views risk the way government views cybersecurity the Prime
Minister launched Australia's cybersecurity strategy in April last year I've been in this role about 15
months and in that time the strategy is a robust document that has quite an ambitious attempt to move us as a
government and us as an economy into a safer place a more resilient place but
there are things that have happened during the year that have moved us quite significantly and I'll talk about three
of them and why talking it at an event like this today makes good sense you may
have noticed in August last year that the census stopped functioning anyone noticed that I did on the night I I
remember I was sick I got woken up to be told that it was offline now the the we
can look at failure as a bad thing or we can look at failure or an event as a
good thing and as a wake-up call and a way for us to change the way we do our business and the census was one of those
that brought into question the digital service delivery of government and and
the number way and number one way in which Australians engage with God is digitally so if people started to
question their ability to do that then that meant we had to go back to I start asking ourselves some questions on the

so the census was a really important point of inflection the next major point of inflection from a cyber security
point of view actually happened during the u.s. elections where it's now widely acknowledged that a foreign state looked
to influence the outcome of the election in the United States the only question now is whether it did influence an
outcome but a foreign state actually going in and and compromising an email
server and essentially daxing a political party to look to change an outcome of election and the third point
of inflection for us amongst many was the wanna cry incident back a few months
ago now you recall that one a crime was a ransomware global ransomware campaign
fastest-growing crime type ransomware happens all the time but the point of difference in wanna cry was it actually
impacted infrastructure in places like the United Kingdom and shut down health services and other such things again
from a political and government point of view you can imagine the types of shivers that sends up the spine of
government agencies you know State Territory and Commonwealth so those three points of inflection have
radically and dramatically increase the amount of political pressure upon us to deliver better cybersecurity for the
Commonwealth and frankly for the nation interestingly I tell you that the pressure from industry upon us as as
government entities to deliver a more resilient economy has also increased and perhaps most importantly of all the
public itself is demanding that type of shift the public that we do here is you're probably a nice discussion but
who's here is from from government but is camber after all so it's about

that I think have have shifted with that pressure the first is rather than
talking about security we talk more about resilience that's a good thing because
really if you're not resilient if you can't provide your services no point
having security and the other most important one is a shift from talking about compliance to that of risk
compliance is important I don't want you to think that I'm saying that that information security manuals and and all
the guidance that we have on what to do is bad it is good and it needs to be followed but this is a risk discussion
compliance is there to drive down risk and I'm going to make a potentially controversial statement to you to say
that our risk aversion as government actually increases our risk we accrete
risk because we fail to move as fast as we could we're creat risk if we think that just
by being compliant we are reducing risk because those things do not actually
work in other words by moving slowly and by relying just upon our compliance
mechanisms we increase risk for the very people that we serve and we just hope

that risk I'd say to you please don't so please innovate because again I I
wear the joy associated with those things and and and so why why cloud and
I'm not spooking for any particular cloud platform I want to say that the types of things that I think helped us reduce risk the first is particularly
for small agencies we have a skills gap we have a skills gap globally in terms
of cybersecurity we certainly have a skills gap in Australia and if you run small agencies or medium-sized agencies
we have skills gap inside those agencies any platform that will be run
professionally for us is a good thing that's a good thing because especially
if it's a globally tested platform we get the benefits of the globe we get the

must make sure that you deal with those issues so the other important thing we
have to do is make sure that we invest in actually migrating legacy apps
